None of them made a real difference, and some were potentially harmful.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'That‚Äôs the damning conclusion of multiple studies published in the last few months. In June, the Turing Institute, the UK‚Äôs national center for data science and AI, put out a report summing up discussions at a series of workshops it held in late 2020. The clear consensus was that'}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' AI tools had made little, if any, impact'}, 'url': 'https://www.turing.ac.uk/sites/default/files/2021-06/data-science-and-ai-in-the-age-of-covid_full-report_2.pdf', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' in the fight against covid.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Not fit for clinical use'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'This echoes the results of two major studies that assessed hundreds of predictive tools developed last year. Wynants is lead author of one of them, a'}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' review in the British Medical Journal'}, 'url': 'https://www.bmj.com/content/369/bmj.m1328', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' that is still being updated as new tools are released and existing ones tested. She and her colleagues have looked at 232 algorithms for diagnosing patients or predicting how sick those with the disease might get. They found that none of them were fit for clinical use. Just two have been singled out as being promising enough for future testing.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúIt‚Äôs shocking,‚Äù says Wynants. ‚ÄúI went into it with some worries, but this exceeded my fears.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Wynants‚Äôs study is backed up by another large review carried out by Derek Driggs, a machine-learning researcher at the University of Cambridge, and his colleagues, and published in Nature Machine Intelligence. This team'}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' zoomed in on deep-learning models for diagnosing covid'}, 'url': 'https://www.nature.com/articles/s42256-021-00307-0', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' and predicting patient risk from medical images, such as chest x-rays and chest computer tomography (CT) scans. They looked at 415 published tools and, like Wynants and her colleagues, concluded that none were fit for clinical use.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúThis pandemic was a big test for AI and medicine,‚Äù says Driggs, who is himself working on a machine-learning tool to help doctors during the pandemic. ‚ÄúIt would have gone a long way to getting the public on our side,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt think we passed that test.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockRelatedArticles', 'title': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'articles': [{'_': 'PageRelatedArticle', 'url': 'https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/04/27/1000658/google-medical-ai-accurate-lab-real-life-clinic-covid-diabetes-retina-disease/', 'webpage_id': 6712606878499335462, 'title': 'Google‚Äôs medical AI was super accurate in a lab. Real life was a different story.', 'description': 'If AI is really going to make a difference to patients we need to know how it works when real humans get their hands on it, in real situations.', 'photo_id': 5853621429369678684, 'author': 'Will Douglas Heaven', 'published_date': datetime.datetime(2020, 4, 27, 17, 22, 45, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Both teams found that researchers repeated the same basic errors in the way they trained or tested their tools. Incorrect assumptions about the data often meant that the trained models did not work as claimed.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Wynants and Driggs still believe AI has the potential to help. But they are concerned that it could be harmful if built in the wrong way because they could miss diagnoses or underestimate risk for vulnerable patients. ‚ÄúThere is a lot of hype about machine-learning models and what they can do today,‚Äù says Driggs.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Unrealistic expectations encourage the use of these tools before they are ready. Wynants and Driggs both say that a few of the algorithms they looked at have already been used in hospitals, and some are being marketed by private developers. ‚ÄúI fear that they may have harmed patients,‚Äù says Wynants.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'So what went wrong? And how do we bridge that gap? If there‚Äôs an upside, it is that the pandemic has made it clear to many researchers that the way AI tools are built needs to change. ‚ÄúThe pandemic has put problems in the spotlight that we‚Äôve been dragging along for some time,‚Äù says Wynants.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'What went wrong'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Many of the problems that were uncovered are linked to the poor quality of the data that researchers used to develop their tools. Information about covid patients, including medical scans, was collected and shared in the middle of a global pandemic, often by the doctors struggling to treat those patients. Researchers wanted to help quickly, and these were the only public data sets available. But this meant that many tools were built using mislabeled data or data from unknown sources.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Driggs highlights the problem of what he calls Frankenstein data sets, which are spliced together from multiple sources and can contain duplicates. This means that some tools end up being tested on the same data they were trained on, making them appear more accurate than they are.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'It also muddies the origin of certain data sets. This can mean that researchers miss important features that skew the training of their models. Many unwittingly used a data set that contained chest scans of children who did not have covid as their examples of what non-covid cases looked like. But as a result, the AIs learned to identify kids, not covid.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Driggs‚Äôs group trained its own model using a data set that contained a mix of scans taken when patients were lying down and standing up. Because patients scanned while lying down were more likely to be seriously ill, the AI learned wrongly to predict serious covid risk from a person‚Äôs position.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In yet other cases, some AIs were found to be picking up on the text font that certain hospitals used to label the scans. As a result, fonts from hospitals with more serious caseloads became predictors of covid risk.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Errors like these seem obvious in hindsight. They can also be fixed by adjusting the models, if researchers are aware of them. It is possible to acknowledge the shortcomings and release a less accurate, but less misleading model. But many tools were developed either by AI researchers who lacked the medical expertise to spot flaws in the data or by medical researchers who lacked the mathematical skills to compensate for those flaws.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'A more subtle problem Driggs highlights is incorporation bias, or bias introduced at the point a data set is labeled. For example, many medical scans were labeled according to whether the radiologists who created them said they showed covid. But that embeds, or incorporates, any biases of that particular doctor into the ground truth of a data set. It would be much better to label a medical scan with the result of a PCR test rather than one doctor‚Äôs opinion, says Driggs. But there isn‚Äôt always time for statistical niceties in busy hospitals.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'That hasn‚Äôt stopped some of these tools from being rushed into clinical practice. Wynants says it isn‚Äôt clear which ones are being used or how. Hospitals will sometimes say that they are using a tool only for research purposes, which makes it hard to assess how much doctors are relying on them. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of secrecy,‚Äù she says.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Wynants asked one company that was marketing deep-learning algorithms to share information about its approach but did not hear back. She later found several published models from researchers tied to this company, all of them with a high risk of bias. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt actually know what the company implemented,‚Äù she says.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'According to Wynants, some hospitals are even signing nondisclosure agreements with medical AI vendors. When she asked doctors what algorithms or software they were using, they sometimes told her they weren‚Äôt allowed to say.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'How to fix it'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'What‚Äôs the fix? Better data would help, but in times of crisis that‚Äôs a big ask. It‚Äôs more important to make the most of the data sets we have. The simplest move would be for AI teams to collaborate more with clinicians, says Driggs. Researchers also need to share their models and disclose how they were trained so that others can test them and build on them. ‚ÄúThose are two things we could do today,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAnd they would solve maybe 50% of the issues that we identified.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Getting hold of data would also be easier if formats were standardized, says Bilal Mateen, a doctor who leads the clinical technology team at the Wellcome Trust, a global health research charity based in London.\xa0'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockRelatedArticles', 'title': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'articles': [{'_': 'PageRelatedArticle', 'url': 'https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/04/23/1000410/ai-triage-covid-19-patients-health-care/', 'webpage_id': 6712606879339883012, 'title': 'Doctors are using AI to triage covid-19 patients. The tools may be here to stay', 'description': 'Rizwan Malik had always had an interest in AI. As the lead radiologist at the Royal Bolton Hospital, run by the UK‚Äôs National Health Service (NHS), he saw its potential to make his job easier. In his hospital, patients often had to wait six hours or more for a specialist to look at their x-rays.‚Ä¶', 'photo_id': 5842807672380959562, 'author': 'Karen Hao', 'published_date': datetime.datetime(2020, 4, 23, 14, 0, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Another problem Wynants, Driggs, and Mateen all identify is that most researchers rushed to develop their own models, rather than working together or improving existing ones. The result was that the collective effort of researchers around the world produced hundreds of mediocre tools, rather than a handful of properly trained and tested ones.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúThe models are so similar‚Äîthey almost all use the same techniques with minor tweaks, the same inputs‚Äîand they all make the same mistakes,‚Äù says Wynants. ‚ÄúIf all these people making new models instead tested models that were already available, maybe we‚Äôd have something that could really help in the clinic by now.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In a sense, this is an old problem with research. Academic researchers have'}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' few career incentives to share work or validate existing results'}, 'url': 'https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/11/12/1011944/artificial-intelligence-replication-crisis-science-big-tech-google-deepmind-facebook-openai/', 'webpage_id': 6712606879285738711}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. There‚Äôs no reward for pushing through the last mile that takes tech from ‚Äúlab bench to bedside,‚Äù says Mateen.\xa0'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'To address this issue, the World Health Organization is considering an emergency data-sharing contract that would kick in during international health crises. message : When I got started on Python for Machine Learning, this is where I spent most of my time:

‚úÖ Codecademy - for learning Python fundamentals
‚úÖ HackerRank - for practice
‚úÖ Official documentation - for going deep 

Books:
‚úÖ Data Science from Scratch
‚úÖ Hands-On Machine Learning

   These gave me a bit of theory & practice. It's important to keep at it once you have started a book or course. It's easy to dismiss an educational resource if you haven't committed to it. Be careful of following bad advice. You almost always end up creating your own path.  (credits: elvis)

message : Where to get data for your next machine learning project?

    An overview of 8 amazing resources to accelerate your next project with data! 

üìå Google Datasets
  Easy to search Datasets on Google Dataset Search engine as it is to search for anything on Google Search! You just enter the topic on which you need to find a Dataset.

üìå Papers with Code Datasets 
An exclusive collection of 4053 machine learning datasets with a supreme search and a good composition of datasets .

üìå Kaggle Dataset
 Explore, analyze, and share quality data. 

üìå Big Bad NLP Datasets 
  One of the best sources for sophisticated Natural Language Processing datasets

üìå Hugging Face Datasets 
 Well known for NLP but good news hugging face is expanding and they can add datasets for machine learning soon, they have 921 datasets. 

üìå Open Data on AWS 
  This registry exists to help people discover and share datasets that are available via AWS resources

üìå Awesome Public Datasets
  A topic-centric list of HQ open datasets. 

üìå Azure public data sets
  This one has public data sets for testing and prototyping. 

üìå Carnegie Mellon University
  A listing of 750 databases, datasets, and research support tools.

Bonus: This articles on Kdnuggets covers around 80 datasets sources of the datasets. Enjoy machine learning.

message : NLP course: A Code-First Introduction to Natural Language Processing by fast.ai 

  This course was originally taught in the University of San Francisco MS in Data Science program. There have been many major advances in NLP in the last few years, and new state-of-the-art results are being achieved every month. NLP is still very much a field in flux, with best practices changing and new standards not yet settled on. This  makes for an exciting time to learn NLP.

This course teaches:

- Whats NLP?
- Regex, SVD
- Naive bayes, tokenization
- Neural network approaches like RNNs, 
seq2seq, attention and transformers arch.
- Bias, disinformation and ethics
- Seq2Seq translation and the Transformer
- Transfer learning for NLP

This is one of the FREE Best NLP course in my opinion.

Blog: bit.ly/3whz1nh

YouTube Playlist: https://bit.ly/3yk7V0A

message : Applications for the AI Residency Program at AI4Bharat, an initiative by Dr Khapra and Dr Kumar from IIT Madras are now open!

It is a one year program that develops young researchers from India and trains them to build cutting edge AI models and solutions.

Some of the benefits of the program include:
1. Opportunity to work with faculty from IIT Madras on India specific problems
2. Opportunities to present at conferences
3. Access to compute infrastructure to train your models
4. A stipend of Rs 50,000 per month

Who can apply?

Graduates with a Bachelor's degree in CSE or related fields in the last 2 years (2019 or later). 

They should also have good programming skills, projects on GitHub/Kaggle, understand Deep Learning (through online certification or course at University) and experience training and evaluating Deep Learning models.

Sounds interesting? Then apply here:
https://ai4bharat.typeform.com/to/itFOKhQY

date : 2020-12-31 04:07:57+00:00
message :   Many Data Science aspirants struggle to find good projects to get a start in Data science or Machine Learning.

   Here is the list of few Data Science projects (found on kaggle), it covers Basics of Python, Advanced Statistics, Supervised Learning (Regression and Classification problems)

1. Basic python and statistics

Pima Indians :- https://www.kaggle.com/uciml/pima-indians-diabetes-database
Cardio Goodness fit :- https://www.kaggle.com/saurav9786/cardiogoodfitness
Automobile :- https://www.kaggle.com/toramky/automobile-dataset

2. Advanced Statistics

Game of Thrones:-https://www.kaggle.com/mylesoneill/game-of-thrones
World University Ranking:-https://www.kaggle.com/mylesoneill/world-university-rankings
IMDB Movie Dataset:- https://www.kaggle.com/carolzhangdc/imdb-5000-movie-dataset

3. Supervised Learning

a) Regression Problems

How much did it rain :- https://www.kaggle.com/c/how-much-did-it-rain-ii/overview
Inventory Demand:- https://www.kaggle.com/c/grupo-bimbo-inventory-demand
Property Inspection predictiion:- https://www.kaggle.com/c/liberty-mutual-group-property-inspection-prediction
Restaurant Revenue prediction:- https://www.kaggle.com/c/restaurant-revenue-prediction/data
IMDB Box office Prediction:-https://www.kaggle.com/c/tmdb-box-office-prediction/overview

b) Classification problems

Employee Access challenge :- https://www.kaggle.com/c/amazon-employee-access-challenge/overview
Titanic :- https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic
San Francisco crime:- https://www.kaggle.com/c/sf-crime
Customer satisfcation:-https://www.kaggle.com/c/santander-customer-satisfaction
Trip type classification:- https://www.kaggle.com/c/walmart-recruiting-trip-type-classification
Categorize cusine:- https://www.kaggle.com/c/whats-cooking

    These are the links of competitions, from there previous notebooks can be checked to begin with, Hope it will be helpful üòäüòä

We have had no bug reports or a blocking bug at all. On distributed compute it really shines and is easier to use than TensorFlow, which for data parallelisms was pretty complicated.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Padwick says the popularity and simplicity of the PyTorch framework gives him an advantage when it comes to ramping up new hires quickly. Some like Apache MXNet or Darknet or Caffe for research, but in production it has to be in a single language, and PyTorch has everything we need to be successful.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Datarock: Cloud-based image analysis for the mining industry'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Founded by a group of geoscientists, Australian startup Datarock is applying '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'computer vision technology'}, 'url': 'https://www.infoworld.com/article/3572553/what-is-computer-vision-ai-for-images-and-video.html', 'webpage_id': 8008384063904745100}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' to the mining industry. More specifically, its deep learning models are helping geologists analyze drill core sample imagery faster than before.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Typically, a geologist would pore over these samples centimeter by centimeter to assess mineralogy and structure, while engineers would look for physical features such as faults, fractures, and rock quality. This process is both slow and prone to human error.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúA computer can see rocks like an engineer would,‚Äù Brenton Crawford, COO of Datarock told InfoWorld. ‚ÄúIf you can see it in the image, we can train a model to analyze it as well as a human.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Similar to Blue River, Datarock uses a variant of the RCNN model in production, with researchers turning to data augmentation techniques to gather enough training data in the early stages.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúFollowing the initial discovery period, the team set about combining techniques to create an image processing workflow for drill core imagery. This involved developing a series of deep learning models that could process raw images into a structured format and segment the important geological information,‚Äù the researchers wrote in a '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'blog post'}, 'url': 'https://medium.com/pytorch/how-datarock-is-using-pytorch-for-more-intelligent-decision-making-d5d1694ba170', 'webpage_id': 3441607289026301176}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Using Datarock‚Äôs technology, clients can get results in half an hour, as opposed to the five or six hours it takes to log findings manually. This frees up geologists from the more laborious parts of their job, Crawford said. However, ‚Äúwhen we automate things that are more difficult, we do get some pushback, and have to explain they are part of this system to train the models and get that feedback loop turning.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Like many companies training deep learning computer vision models, Datarock started with TensorFlow, but soon shifted to PyTorch.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockUnsupported'}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúAt the start we used TensorFlow and it would crash on us for mysterious reasons,‚Äù Duy Tin Truong, machine learning lead at Datarock told InfoWorld. ‚ÄúPyTorch and Detecton2 was released at that time and fitted well with our needs, so after some tests we saw it was easier to debug and work with and occupied less memory, so we converted,‚Äù he said.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Datarock also reported a 4x improvement in inference performance from TensorFlow <============================>
_ : Message
id : 439
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-10-02 01:19:53+00:00
message : AI/DL Certificates:  No one cares about certificates in our business.  Period.  If you learn something while you get the certificate, sure.  Get one print out and post it on your wall then.  It does make an office less boring. 

AI/DL Degrees:  If you do interesting projects, and you gain understanding and skills out of the projects, then an AI degree is good for you.   Otherwise, no one cares about your degrees.  What about a PhD or a master? That depends on the quality of your publications, see below. 

AI/DL Projects:  If you actually do the projects, but not copying from "10-lines to do object detection" you see on-line, and you actually understand the principles of the techniques you are using, then those projects would be great experience for you.  Otherwise, no one cares if you had done 1000 projects in your life. 

AI/DL Publications:  If the writing process makes you think of a novel technique in the field, absolutely!   Or you gain fundamental understanding of a class of algorithms when you research the background, sure that matters a lot!  That's why graduates who has past publications are usually strong candidates for many big companies ML department.  (Make sure you can answer questions about your own publication though!)

AI/DL Blog Posts You Write: If the quality of the blog is like a paper, sure.  But if you just copy from "10-lines to do object detection" , no one cares.  

Great Programming Skill:  If that means you have source-level understanding of a major deep learning framework, wooooh, I would love to see your resume!    What if you know 7 different ways to do string manipulation in python?  That certainly is an interesting programming skill, but programming skill does not equal to ML skill.  So again, no one cares. 

In a nutshell, what matters most is whether you genuinely understand the field. Credits: Arthur Chan

A Beginner's introduction to Programming

Learn Python, Break Python is a hands-on introduction to the Python programming language, written for people who have no experience with programming whatsoever. Hey, we all have to start somewhere. As such, the examples and teaching style used in this text make absolutely no expectations about your prior programming experience. If you've never used a programming language before, leaping into Python might seem a bit scary at first. You don't need to worry. Learning how to program a computer is far from impossible. Anyone can pick up the art of programming with a little time and a bit of patience.

OpenCV: The Untold Story with Satya Mallick 

Ai India would like to announce that our second virtual AI meetup with Satya Mallick (CEO, OpenCV.org) 

About speaker:
Dr. Satya Mallick is the CEO of OpenCV. In 2017, IBM Watson‚Äôs blog named Dr. Mallick as one of the top 30 AI influencers to follow on Twitter. His work has been featured in publications like the BBC, Time, Huffington Post, the Wall Street Journal, Oprah Magazine, TechCrunch, and Theregister UK.

Join us for the second biggest AI Meet-up to know 

To Know How OpenCV was Born?
To Know how it changed the world of Computer Vision? 
To know how it works ?
To know how learn OpenCV and become computer vision expert?
To know how OpenCV AI Kit is gonna fight with Raspberry PI?
To know the about Kickstarter campaign for the OpenCV AI Kit

date : 2020-08-07 00:25:48+00:00
message : Today I found myself oddly satisfied.

     I wrote a simple function - 2 lines of code. But that function has been used 100 times today. And every time I use it, I think this silly little function is saving me so much time. 

   This led me to an important conclusion. 

    Impact is not measured in how many lines of code you write.

   Impact is measured in how the code you write improves your life and how many times it‚Äôs used.- Matt Dancho

<============================>
_ : Message
id : 402
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-07-23 06:05:51+00:00
message : Yes, you can.  You just have to get good at programming.üòä

Well, if you are in a junior position in a company, may be you can get away from programming for the first few months..... But then you would find that all customizations you want to do require programming skills. 

So how do you get good at programming then?  Just like many skills, you really want to learn by practicing.   The first program you want to learn for any language is to print "Hello World" on the screen.    Then you want to learn the basics of control flows structure such as usage of "if"-, "for-", "while-" statements.   Write them yourself on paper, then type it up, go through the process of compilation.  

As a principle, I suggest you learn programming by both your intellect and your hands. e.g. If you never write a certain program, copy one and see if you can get it running.  Then ask whether you understand the program.   Challenge yourself then to rewrite a program your own.   Eventually, come up with a change that is innovative, then perhaps teach others about what you learn. 

Learning from books and classes also work.  But you should know if you only learn from class but never program, we may only call you a theoretician of programming, but not a genuine programmer. 

Finally, always be honest on how you assess your own programming skills.  Programming, much like playing music or pursuing any types of art, is a search of truth about yourself.  When in doubt, staying humble is the least you should do.
-Arthur Chan

_ : Message
id : 394
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-07-07 04:41:13+00:00
message : The life of a Machine Learning engineer consists of long stretches of frustration and a few moments of joy!  

First, struggle to get your model to produce good results on your training data. You visualize your training data, clean it up, and train again. One fine day your PyTorch model is trained to perfection and it is ready for production.
That‚Äôs pure joy!

You are proud of the accuracy, you mark your task as completed in your project tracker, and inform your CTO the model is ready.

 She shakes her head in disapproval and informs you the model is not ready for production! Training a model is not enough. You need to modify the model so it is efficient at run time

-Satya Mallick, (Interim CEO at OpenCV.org )

message : Coursera courses are now FREE for students ü•≥üéâ (thanx to Andrew Ng)

 Learning with Coursera for college, University students
   Starting today, college and university students around the world can learn and earn certificates on Coursera for free. Current undergraduate, graduate, or recently graduated students with a verified school email can sign up to get free access to over 3,800 courses, 150 Guided Projects, 400 Specializations, and 11 Professional Certificates. They can enroll in programs for free until July 31 ‚Äî no credit card required. Once enrolled, they will have until Sept. 30, 2020, to complete the programs.

_ : Message
id : 374
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-05-15 01:45:55+00:00
message : New Data Scientists - When you learn, it's easy to get distracted by Machine Learning & Deep Learning terms like "XGBoost", "Neural Networks", "RNN", "LSTM" or Advanced Technologies like "Spark", "Julia", "Scala", "Go", etc. 

Don't get bogged down trying to learn every new term & technology you come across. 

Instead, focus on foundations. 
- data wrangling
- visualizing
- exploring
- modeling
- understanding the results. 

The best tools are often basic, Build yourself up. You'll advance much faster. Keep learning!

_ : Message
id : 371
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-05-03 01:29:07+00:00
message : YOLO v4 released! üéâüéâ
YOLO Is Back! Version 4 Boasts Improved Speed and Accuracy

The introduction of state-of-the-art, real-time object detection system YOLO (You only look once) in 2016 was a milestone in object detection research and led to better, faster and more accurate computer vision algorithms. Unfortunately, two months ago the father of YOLO Joseph Redmon announced he was leaving the field of computer vision due to concerns regarding the possible negative impact of his work. Redmon‚Äôs withdrawal triggered online debates and raised an important question: would there still be YOLO updates in the future?

Well, to the relief of many in the computer vision (CV) community, the answer is yes! The official YOLO Github account released an updated YOLO Version 4 last Friday.

Compared with the previous YOLOv3, YOLOv4 has the following advantages:
üëâ It is an efficient and powerful object detection model that enables anyone with a 1080 Ti or 2080 Ti GPU to train a super fast and accurate object detector.
üëâ The influence of state-of-the-art ‚ÄúBag-of-Freebies‚Äù and ‚ÄúBag-of-Specials‚Äù object detection methods during detector training has been verified.
üëâ The modified state-of-the-art methods, including CBN (Cross-iteration batch normalization), PAN (Path aggregation network), etc., are now more efficient and suitable for single GPU training.

The authors used s combined the following new features to make their design suitable for efficient training and detection:
üëâ Weighted-Residual-Connections (WRC)
üëâ Cross-Stage-Partial-Connections (CSP), 
üëâ A new backbone that can enhance learning capability of CNN.
üëâ Cross mini-Batch Normalization (CmBN), represents a CBN modified version which assumes a batch contains four mini-batches
üëâ Self-adversarial-training (SAT), represents a new data augmentation technique that operates in 2 forward backward stages
üëâ Mish-activation, A novel self regularized non-monotonic neural activation function 
üëâ Mosaic data augmentation, represents a new data augmentation method that mixes 4 training images instead of a single image.
üëâ DropBlock regularization, a better regularization method for CNN
üëâ CIoU loss, achieves better convergence speed and accuracy on the BBox regression problem.
YOLOv4‚Äôs excellent speed and accuracy and the well-written paper are a great contribution to engineering and academics. The update also illustrates an encouraging promotion and development of open source software: even if the father of YOLO has abandoned model updates, others can maintain and continue to promote the development of the powerful tools which we are increasingly reliant on.
The source code is on the Project Github. https://github.com/AlexeyAB/darknet
 The paper YOLOv4: Optimal Speed and Accuracy of Object Detection is on arxiv. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2004.10934.pdf

'PageBlockAuthorDate', 'author': {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kyle Wiggers'}, 'url': 'https://venturebeat.com/author/kylewiggers/', 'webpage_id': 0}, 'published_date': datetime.datetime(2020, 4, 29, 15, 0, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Facebook AI Research (FAIR), Facebook‚Äôs AI and machine learning division, today detailed work on a comprehensive AI chatbot framework called Blender. FAIR claims that Blender, which is available in open source on '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'GitHub'}, 'url': 'https://parl.ai/projects/blender/', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ', is the largest-ever open-domain chatbot and outperforms existing approaches to generating dialogue while ‚Äúfeel[ing] more human,‚Äù according to human evaluators.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'FAIR says Blender is the culmination of years of research to combine empathy, knowledge, and personality into one system. To this end, the underlying models ‚Äî which benefit from improved decoding and skill blending techniques ‚Äî contain up to 9.4 billion parameters (configuration variables that define skill on a given problem), or 3.6 times more than previous systems.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Blender promises to make interactions with conversational AI systems like Alexa, Siri, and Cortana more natural than before, whether in enterprise, industrial, or consumer-facing contexts. That‚Äôs because they‚Äôre able to ask and answer a wide range of questions; display knowledge about specific topics; and express sentiments like empathy, seriousness, or playfulness as circumstances dictate.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Blending skills and generation strategies'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'To achieve Blender‚Äôs state-of-the-art performance, researchers at FAIR focused on two engineering steps: blending skills and generation strategy.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúBlending skills‚Äù refers to selecting tasks that outperform larger models that lack tuning. As the FAIR researchers point out in a paper, chatbot improvements can be attained by fine-tuning models on data that emphasizes desirable conversational skills. As it turns out, tuning can also minimize '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'undesirable'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' traits learned from large data sets, such as toxicity.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'With respect to generation strategy, the choice of decoding algorithm ‚Äî the algorithm used to generate text from a language model ‚Äî has an outsized impact on a chatbot‚Äôs responses. Because the length of a bot‚Äôs responses tend to correspond to human judgments of quality, decoders that strike an appropriate balance are desirable. Responses that are too short are typically perceived as dull or showing a lack of interest, while those that are too long imply waffling or distraction.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5860701008647269066, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Above: A conversation with a Blender chatbot. Blender‚Äôs responses are in blue.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Over the course of these engineering steps, the researchers tested three types of model architectures, all of which used '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Transformers'}, 'url': 'https://venturebeat.com/2020/02/10/microsoft-trains-worlds-largest-transformer-language-model/', 'webpage_id': 6273363635610002354}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' as a base. Transformers ‚Äî a Google innovation ‚Äî contain neurons (mathematical functions) arranged in layers that transmit signals from input data and adjust the strength (weights) of each connection, as with all deep neural networks. That‚Äôs how they extract features and learn to make predictions, but Transformers also have attention. This means every output element is connected to every input element and the weightings between them are calculated dynamically.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'First up was a retriever model that, given a dialogue history (or context) as input, selected the next dialogue response by scoring a large set of candidate responses and outputting the highest-scoring one. The FAIR researchers employed a poly-encoder architecture that encoded features of the context using representations attended to by each candidate response, which they say resulted in improved performance while remaining ‚Äútractable‚Äù to compute, compared with other architectures, like cross-encoders.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The second model was a generator that produced responses rather than retrieving them from a fixed set. Three models were considered by size, ranging from 90 million parameters to 2.7 billion parameters to 9.4 billion parameters.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The third model attempted to address issues with the generator, namely its tendency to synthesize repetitive responses and to ‚Äúhallucinate‚Äù knowledge. It took a ‚Äúretrieve and refine‚Äù (RetNRef) approach, where the above-described retrieval model produced a response when provided a dialogue history, which was then appended to the input sequence of the generator. In this way, the generator learned when to copy elements of responses from the retriever and when not to so it could output more interesting, engaging, and ‚Äúvibrant‚Äù responses. (Retriever models produce human-written responses that tend to include more vibrant language than standard generative models.)'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5858345867625474753, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The FAIR team paired a Wizard Generative model with another retriever that together determined when to incorporate knowledge into chatbot responses. The two models produce a set of initial knowledge candidates and then rank those candidates, after which they select a single sentence and use it to condition response generation. A classifier chooses whether to perform retrieval or not on a per-dialogue basis so as to avoid serving knowledge when it‚Äôs not required.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockSubheader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Decoding'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'For the generative models, the FAIR researchers used a beam search decoder method to generate responses to given dialogue contexts. Beam search maintains a set of partially decoded sequences, called hypotheses, that are appended to form sequences and then scored so the best sequences bubble to the top.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'To control the length of the chatbot‚Äôs responses, the FAIR team considered two approaches: a hard constraint on the minimum generation length and a classifier that predicted the length of responses and set the minimum generation length constraint to its corresponding prediction. The latter was more complex but resulted in variable-length responses to questions, ensuring the chatbot served long responses when they seemed appropriate.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Training the models'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'To prep the various models that make up Blender, the researchers first performed pretraining, a step that conditions machine learning models for particular tasks. They used Facebook‚Äôs own Fairseq, a toolkit that supports the training of custom language models, with data samples from a Reddit corpus containing 1.5 billion comments (with two sets of 360,000 comments each reserved for validation and testing) pruned for known bots, non-English subreddits, deleted comments, comments with a URL, and comments of a certain length.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5860491049171004116, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Next, the FAIR team fine-tuned the models using another Facebook-developed suite ‚Äî ParlAI ‚Äî designed for training and testing dialogue models. One training corpus selected was ConvAI2, which contains 140,000 utterances involving paired volunteers getting to know each other by asking and answering friendly questions. Another was Empathetic Dialogues, which consists of 50,000 crowdsourced utterances grounded in an emotional situation. Yet another data set ‚Äî the Wizard of Wikipedia ‚Äî comprises 194,000 utterances of 1,250 topics, where each conversation begins with a randomly chosen topic and the goal is to display expert knowledge.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'A fourth fine-tuning data set ‚Äî Blended Skill Talk ‚Äî aimed to blend the previous three sets (ConvAI2, Empathetic Dialogues, and Wizard of Wikipedia) to combine their respective skills during dialogue. Here, 76,000 utterances were collected with a guided and unguided human speaker, where the guided speaker could select utterances suggested by bots trained on the three individual data sets.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Evaluations'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Post-training, the researchers evaluated Blender‚Äôs performance by comparing it with Google‚Äôs latest '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Meena'}, 'url': 'https://venturebeat.com/2020/01/28/meena-is-googles-attempt-at-making-true-conversational-ai/', 'webpage_id': 6273363636410768858}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' chatbot, a machine learning model with 2.6 billion parameters. Human volunteers were tasked with answering two questions ‚Äî ‚ÄúWho would you prefer to talk to for a long conversation?‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhich speaker sounds more human?‚Äù ‚Äî given 100 publicly released and randomized logs from Meena and the same number of logs generated by Blender. In each case, the volunteers were shown series of dialogues between humans paired with the respective chatbots.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The topics of conversation ranged from cooking, music, movies, and pets to yoga, veganism, instruments, and malls ‚Äî with the Blender models often going into detail when asked and naming relevant stores, bands, movies, actors, pet species, and pet names. In one example, Blender offered a nuanced answer to a question about how Bach compared with Justin Beiber, while a request that Blender write a song indeed yielded lyrics ‚Äî although nothing particularly poetic.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5860457312202894102, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'When presented with chats showing Meena in action and chats showing Blender in action, 67% of the evaluators said the best-performing Blender-powered chatbot ‚Äî the one with a generative model containing 9.4 billion parameters pretrained on the Blended Skill Talk corpus ‚Äî sounded more human. About 75% said they‚Äôd rather have a long conversation with the 2.7 billion-parameter fine-tuned model than with Meena. And in an A/B comparison between human-to-human and human-to-Blender conversations, the volunteers expressed a preference for models fine-tuned on Blended Skill Talk 49% of the time, while models trained only on public domain conversations were preferred just 36% of the time.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Problematically, further experiments showed that Blender sometimes produced responses in the style of offensive samples from the training corpora ‚Äî mostly from Reddit comments. The FAIR researchers say that fine-tuning on the Blended Skill Talk data set mitigated this to an extent but addressing it comprehensively would require using an unsafe word filter and a kind of safety classifier.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5860442558990232333, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Above: Here, Blender repeats and contradicts itself, forgets, and hallucinates knowledge.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Of course, the FAIR researchers don‚Äôt claim to have solved the problem of open-domain conversation. In fact, they outline several of Blender‚Äôs major limitations:'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockOrderedList', 'items': [{'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Vocabulary usage:'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' Even the best Blender models tend to generate common phrases too frequently, such as ‚Äúdo you like,‚Äù ‚Äúlot of fun,‚Äù and ‚Äúhave any hobbies.‚Äù'}]}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Nontrivial repetition:'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' The models often repeat what is said to them. For instance, they‚Äôll say that they had a pet dog if a conversation partner mentions a pet dog, or that they like the same bands as the person they‚Äôre speaking with.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Contradiction and forgetfulness:'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' Blender models contradict themselves, albeit to a lesser degree in the larger models. They also fail to make the logical link that they shouldn‚Äôt ask questions they‚Äôve asked before (to avoid the appearance of ‚Äúforgetting‚Äù).'}]}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Knowledge and factual correctness:'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' It‚Äôs relatively easy to goad Blender models into making factual errors, particularly when exploring a topic deeply.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Conversation length and memory:'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' Blender conversations would likely be dull and repetitive over the course of several days or weeks of conversation, the FAIR researchers say ‚Äî especially considering Blender can‚Äôt remember earlier conversations.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Deeper understanding:'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' The Blender models lack the ability to learn concepts through further conversation, and they have no way of grounding to entities, actions, and experiences in the real world.'}]}}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Addressing all this would likely require new model architectures, which the FAIR team says it‚Äôs exploring. It‚Äôs also focused on building stronger classifiers to filter out harmful language in dialogues, as well as techniques to tamp down on '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'gender bias'}, 'url': 'https://venturebeat.com/2020/04/22/stereoset-measures-racism-sexism-and-other-forms-of-bias-in-ai-language-models/', 'webpage_id': 6273363636083879742}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' in chatbots generally.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúWe‚Äôre excited about the progress we‚Äôve made in improving open-domain chatbots,‚Äù wrote Facebook in a blog post. ‚ÄúHowever, building a truly intelligent dialogue agent that can chat like a human remains one of the largest open challenges in AI today ‚Ä¶ True progress in the field depends on reproducibility ‚Äî the opportunity to build upon the best technology possible. We believe that releasing models is essential to enable full, reliable insights into their capabilities.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The pretrained and fine-tuned Blender models with 90 million parameters, 2.7 billion parameters, and 9.4 billion parameters are available on GitHub, along with a script for interacting with the bot (with safety filtering built in). <============================>
_ : Message
id : 362
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-04-26 01:23:42+00:00
message : RIP most #machinelearning models in production!

Current pandemic absolutely messed up all kinds of predictive models: customer segmentation, sales & demand forecasts, churn analysis, logistics optimization... pretty much anything that attempts to model human behavior in the slightest, directly or indirectly. 

Business KPIs are completely different now.

#AutoML became a joke. 

Historical #data became obsolete. 

Actually worse! Chances are historical data will stay irrelevant even when things calm down because things will be in a completely different state-space. 

Time to throw away your nice and pretty cross-validation results & p-values. 

Probably a good time to stop worrying about #Azure vs. #AWS, #Python vs. #R, #TensorFlow vs. #PyTorch as well.

One of the finest reminders of how bad ML is when it comes to "out-of-distribution generalization". 

I hope this will humble us data folks down.

Makes me kind of glad to be working heavily on #ComputerVision and #IndustrialIoT with tasks that are less affected by such global distribution shifts. 

Product defects on a factory belt and hydrogen peroxide levels in a tank are still the same. For now. 

Better wash our hands, simplify the ML pipelines and start collecting new data!
source: LinkedIn

_ : Message
id : 360
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2020-04-24 16:16:56+00:00
message : What are the few things to remember in the process of becoming machine learning engineer?

üëâ Machine Learning is not only algorithms. There is much larger process to delivering outcomes apart from algorithm portion 

üëâ Data does not always come in single nice CSV file  

üëâ Feature engineering via business and data understanding can keep model simple and explainable 

üëâ Bad data beautifully visualization is still bad data

üëâ Start with simple model and incrementally go to complex ones.. Keep your model simple as much as possible. Does the difference in performance justify additional complexity is a key question to ask for the respective business process

üëâ 4 function that many focus on read_csv, fit, predict, evaluate will solve only around small percentage of your problem. Remaining is where you standout

üëâ Focus on the process to insight and not the tool. Scikit learn is one just tool, be ready and open to work on any tool

üëâ Flask is not the only solution for model deployment

üëâ Identifying the metrics by itself is time consuming. Say in fraud detection focusing too much on fraudulent transaction can result in high false positive resulting in deteriorating customer experience. Your metrics has to be balanced in some cases

message : FREE Virtual Meetup Series

Getting started with AI within 100mins 

Overview
Come join us on the first-ever meetup as we have an engaging discussion and a value-adding conversation around - the landscape of artificial intelligence, deep learning with hands-on CNN. We will elaborate on what AI actually is, how it is all set to power the future, how it is driving businesses in around the globe in today's day and age, how to get started with artificial intelligence, how to build a strong AI portfolio and opportunities for freshers in AI, ML, and DS. This event also gives an opportunity to have hands-on Deep learning, you will get realtime experience to make your hands dirty in building the CNN model.

*****
This first series of part 1 is for novices. If you're more advanced, consider this as either as a refresher or join second parts for junior, intermediate and advanced sessions.

All the session in this series will be taken on google Hangouts, participants will get joining link in the confirmation mail of the meetup,  We will start with a 5 min introduction to give time for people to join. We will pause a moment after each slide so people can ask the question. You can type your question in the chat-box.

Date: 4th April 2020, 7:30 PM to 10 PM

07:30-08.00   Part 1  Introduction to AI for newbies

08.00-08.45    Part 2  Neural Networks
08:45-09:00    Lab 1 (Hands-on )

09:00-09:40   Part 3 Convolutional Neural Networks
09:40-10:20   Lab 2 (Hands-on )

Registration link https://bit.ly/aiindiameetups
