Cross-correlation'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Convolution in Deep Learning (single channel version, multi-channel version)'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '3D Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '1 x 1 Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Convolution Arithmetic'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Transposed Convolution (Deconvolution, checkerboard artifacts)'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dilated Convolution (Atrous Convolution)'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Separable Convolution (Spatially Separable Convolution, Depthwise Convolution)'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Flattened Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Grouped Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Shuffled Grouped Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageListOrderedItemText', 'num': '', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Pointwise Grouped Convolution'}}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '1. Convolution v.s. Cross-correlation'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Convolution is a widely used technique in signal processing, image processing, and other engineering / science fields. In Deep Learning, a kind of model architecture, Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), is named after this technique. However, convolution in deep learning is essentially the cross-correlation in signal / image processing. There is a subtle difference between these two operations.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Without diving too deep into details, here is the difference. In signal / image processing, convolution is defined as:'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928065058129160564, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'It is defined as the integral of the product of the two functions after one is reversed and shifted. The following visualization demonstrated the idea.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928393936659917209, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Convolution in signal processing. The filter g is reversed, and then slides along the horizontal axis. For every position, we calculate the area of the intersection between f and reversed g. The intersection area is the convolution value at that specific position. Image is adopted and edited from this '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'http://fourier.eng.hmc.edu/e161/lectures/convolution/index.html', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Here, function g is the filter. It‚Äôs reversed, and then slides along the horizontal axis. For every position, we calculate the area of the intersection between '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'f'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' and reversed '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'g'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. That intersection area is the convolution value at that specific position.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'On the other hand, cross-correlation is known as sliding dot product or sliding inner-product of two functions. The filter in cross-correlation is not reversed. It directly slides through the function f. The intersection area between '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'f'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' and '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'g'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' is the cross-correlation. The plot below demonstrates the difference between correlation and cross-correlation.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928017865028512149, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Difference between convolution and cross-correlation in signal processing. Image is adopted and edited from '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Wikipedia'}, 'url': 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolution', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In Deep Learning, the filters in convolution are not reversed. Rigorously speaking, it‚Äôs cross-correlation. We essentially perform element-wise multiplication and addition. But it‚Äôs a convention to just call it convolution in deep learning. It is fine because the weights of filters are learned during training. If the reversed function g in the example above is the right function, then after training the learned filter would look like the reversed function g. Thus, there is no need to reverse the filter first before training as in true convolution.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '2. Convolution in Deep Learning'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The purpose of doing convolution is to extract useful features from the input. In image processing, there is a wide range of different filters one could choose for convolution. Each type of filters helps to extract different aspects or features from the input image, e.g. horizontal / vertical / diagonal edges. Similarly, in Convolutional Neural Network, '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'different features are extracted through convolution using filters whose weights are automatically learned during training'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. All these extracted features then are ‚Äòcombined‚Äô to make decisions.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'There are a few advantages of doing convolution, such as weights sharing and translation invariant. Convolution also takes spatial relationship of pixels into considerations. These could be very helpful especially in many computer vision tasks, since those tasks often involve identifying objects where certain components have certain spatially relationship with other components (e.g. a dog‚Äôs body usually links to a head, four legs, and a tail).'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockSubheader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '2.1. Convolution: the single channel version'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5858229830037799769, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Convolution for a single channel. Image is adopted from this '}}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}}, 'url': 'https://towardsdatascience.com/intuitively-understanding-convolutions-for-deep-learning-1f6f42faee1', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'autoplay': True, 'loop': True}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In Deep Learning, convolution is the element-wise multiplication and addition. For an image with 1 channel, the convolution is demonstrated in the figure below. Here the filter is a 3 x 3 matrix with element [[0, 1, 2], [2, 2, 0], [0, 1, 2]]. The filter is sliding through the input. At each position, it‚Äôs doing element-wise multiplication and addition. Each sliding position ends up with one number. The final output is then a 3 x 3 matrix. (Notice that stride = 1 and padding = 0 in this example. These concepts will be described in the section of arithmetic below.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockSubheader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '2.2. Convolution: the multi-channel version'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In many applications, we are dealing with images with multiple channels. A typical example is the RGB image. Each RGB channel emphasizes different aspects of the original image, as illustrated in the following image.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928088792118438301, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Different channels emphasize different aspects of the raw image. The image was taken at Yuanyang, Yunnan, China.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Another example of multi-channel data is the layers in Convolutional Neural Network. A convolutional-net layer usually consists of multiple channels (typically hundreds of channels). Each channel describes different aspects of the previous layer. How do we make transition between layers with different depth? How do we transform a layer with depth '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'n'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' to the following layer with depth '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'm'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '?'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Before describing the process, we would like to clarify a few terminologies: layers, channels, feature maps, filters, and kernels. From a hierarchical point of view, the concepts of layers and filters are at the same level, while channels and kernels are at one level below. Channels and feature maps are the same thing. A layer could have multiple channels (or feature maps): an input layer has 3 channels if the inputs are RGB images. ‚Äúchannel‚Äù is usually used to describe the structure of a ‚Äúlayer‚Äù. Similarly, ‚Äúkernel‚Äù is used to describe the structure of a ‚Äúfilter‚Äù.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5930171189832034741, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Difference between ‚Äúlayer‚Äù (‚Äúfilter‚Äù) and ‚Äúchannel‚Äù (‚Äúkernel‚Äù).'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The difference between filter and kernel is a bit tricky. Sometimes, they are used interchangeably, which could create confusions. Essentially, these two terms have subtle difference. A ‚ÄúKernel‚Äù refers to a 2D array of weights. The term ‚Äúfilter‚Äù is for 3D structures of multiple kernels stacked together. For a 2D filter, filter is same as kernel. But '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'for a 3D filter and most convolutions in deep learning, a filter is a collection of kernels. Each kernel is unique, emphasizing different aspects of the input channel'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'With these concepts, the multi-channel convolution goes as the following. Each kernel is applied onto an input channel of the previous layer to generate one output channel. This is a kernel-wise process. We repeat such process for all kernels to generate multiple channels. Each of these channels are then summed together to form one single output channel. The following illustration should make the process clearer.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Here the input layer is a 5 x 5 x 3 matrix, with 3 channels. The filter is a 3 x 3 x 3 matrix. First, each of the kernels in the filter are applied to three channels in the input layer, separately. Three convolutions are performed, which result in 3 channels with size 3 x 3.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5858067171036365564, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The first step of 2D convolution for multi-channels: each of the kernels in the filter are applied to three channels in the input layer, separately. The image is adopted from this '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://towardsdatascience.com/intuitively-understanding-convolutions-for-deep-learning-1f6f42faee1', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'autoplay': True, 'loop': True}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Then these three channels are summed together (element-wise addition) to form one single channel (3 x 3 x 1). This channel is the result of convolution of the input layer (5 x 5 x 3 matrix) using a filter (3 x 3 x 3 matrix).'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5858228356864017125, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The second step of 2D convolution for multi-channels: then these three channels are summed together (element-wise addition) to form one single channel. The image is adopted from this '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://towardsdatascience.com/intuitively-understanding-convolutions-for-deep-learning-1f6f42faee1', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'autoplay': True, 'loop': True}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Equivalently, we can think of this process as sliding a 3D filter matrix through the input layer. Notice that the input layer and the filter have the same depth (channel number = kernel number). '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The 3D filter moves only in 2-direction, height & width of the image (That‚Äôs why such operation is called as 2D convolution although a 3D filter is used to process 3D volumetric data).'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' At each sliding position, we perform element-wise multiplication and addition, which results in a single number. In the example shown below, the sliding is performed at 5 positions horizontally and 5 positions vertically. Overall, we get a single output channel.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928123349425301942, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Another way to think about 2D convolution: thinking of the process as sliding a 3D filter matrix through the input layer. Notice that the input layer and the filter have the same depth (channel number = kernel number). '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The 3D filter moves only in 2-direction, height & width of the image (That‚Äôs why such operation is called as 2D convolution although a 3D filter is used to process 3D volumetric data). The output is a one-layer matrix.'}}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Now we can see how one can make transitions between layers with different depth. Let‚Äôs say the input layer has '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Din'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' channels, and we want the output layer has '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dout'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' channels. What we need to do is to just apply '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dout'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' filters to the input layer. Each filter has '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Din '}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'kernels. Each filter provides one output channel. After applying '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dout'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' filters, we have '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dout'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' channels, which can then be stacked together to form the output layer.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5927955222930500018, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Standard 2D convolution. Mapping one layer with depth '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Din'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' to another layer with depth '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dout, by using Dout filters'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '3. 3D Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In the last illustration of the previous section, we see that we were actually perform convolution to a 3D volume. But typically, we still call that operation as 2D convolution in Deep Learning. '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'It‚Äôs a 2D convolution on a 3D volumetric data. The filter depth is same as the input layer depth. The 3D filter moves only in 2-direction (height & width of the image). The output of such operation is a 2D image (with 1 channel only).'}}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Naturally, there are 3D convolutions. They are the generalization of the 2D convolution. '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Here in 3D convolution, the filter depth is smaller than the input layer depth (kernel size < channel size). As a result, the 3D filter can move in all 3-direction (height, width, channel of the image)'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. At each position, the element-wise multiplication and addition provide one number. Since the filter slides through a 3D space, the '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'output numbers are arranged in a 3D space as well. The output is then a 3D data.'}}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5927949703897524694, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In 3D convolution, a 3D filter can move in all 3-direction (height, width, channel of the image)'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. At each position, the element-wise multiplication and addition provide one number. Since the filter slides through a 3D space, the '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'output numbers are arranged in a 3D space as well. The output is then a 3D data.'}}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Similar as 2D convolutions which encode spatial relationships of objects in a 2D domain, 3D convolutions can describe the spatial relationships of objects in the 3D space. Such 3D relationship is important for some applications, such as in 3D segmentations / reconstructions of biomedical imagining, e.g. CT and MRI where objects such as blood vessels meander around in the 3D space.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '4. 1 x 1 Convolution'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Since we talked about depth-wise operation in the previous section of 3D convolution, let‚Äôs look at another interesting operation, 1 x 1 convolution.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'You may wonder why this is helpful. Do we just multiply a number to every number in the input layer? Yes and No. The operation is trivial for layers with only one channel. There, we multiply every element by a number.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Things become interesting if the input layer has multiple channels. The following picture illustrates how 1 x 1 convolution works for an input layer with dimension H x W x D. After 1 x 1 convolution with filter size 1 x 1 x D, the output channel is with dimension H x W x 1. If we apply N such 1 x 1 convolutions and then concatenate results together, we could have a output layer with dimension H x W x N.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5930367495607265697, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '1 x 1 convolution, where the filter size is 1 x 1 x D.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Initially, 1 x 1 convolutions were proposed in the Network-in-network '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'paper'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1312.4400', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. They were then highly used in the Google Inception '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'paper'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1409.4842', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1409.4842).', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' A few advantages of 1 x 1 convolutions are:'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockList', 'items': [{'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dimensionality reduction for efficient computations'}}, {'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Efficient low dimensional embedding, or feature pooling'}}, {'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Applying nonlinearity again after convolution'}}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The first two advantages can be observed in the image above. After 1 x 1 convolution, we significantly reduce the dimension depth-wise. Say if the original input has 200 channels, the 1 x 1 convolution will embed these channels (features) into a single channel. The third advantage comes in as after the 1 x 1 convolution, non-linear activation such as ReLU can be added. The non-linearity allows the network to learn more complex function.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'These advantages were described in Google‚Äôs Inception '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'paper'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1409.4842', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' as:'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockBlockquote', 'text': {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚ÄúOne big problem with the above modules, at least in this na√Øve form, is that even a modest number of 5x5 convolutions can be prohibitively expensive on top of a convolutional layer with a large number of filters.\nThis leads to the second idea of the proposed architecture: judiciously applying dimension reductions and projections wherever the computational requirements would increase too much otherwise. This is based on the success of embeddings: even low dimensional embeddings might contain a lot of information about a relatively large image patch‚Ä¶ That is, 1 x 1 convolutions are used to compute reductions before the expensive 3 x 3 and 5 x 5 convolutions. Besides being used as reductions, they also include the use of rectified linear activation which makes them dual-purpose.‚Äù'}}, 'caption': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'One interesting perspective regarding 1 x 1 convolution comes from Yann LeCun ‚ÄúIn Convolutional Nets, there is no such thing as ‚Äúfully-connected layers‚Äù. There are only convolution layers with 1x1 convolution kernels and a full connection table.‚Äù'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928280472213891468, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '5. Convolution Arithmetic'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'We now know how to deal with depth in convolution. Let‚Äôs move on to talk about how to handle the convolution in the other two directions (height & width), as well as important convolution arithmetic.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Here are a few terminologies:'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockList', 'items': [{'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kernel size: kernel is discussed in the previous section. The kernel size defines the field of view of the convolution.'}}, {'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Stride: it defines the step size of the kernel when sliding through the image. Stride of 1 means that the kernel slides through the image pixel by pixel. Stride of 2 means that the kernel slides through image by moving 2 pixels per step (i.e., skipping 1 pixel). We can use stride (>= 2) for downsampling an image.'}}, {'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Padding: the padding defines how the border of an image is handled. A padded convolution (‚Äòsame‚Äô padding in Tensorflow) will keep the spatial output dimensions equal to the input image, by padding 0 around the input boundaries if necessary. On the other hand, unpadded convolution (‚Äòvalid‚Äô padding in Tensorflow) only perform convolution on the pixels of the input image, without adding 0 around the input boundaries. The output size is smaller than the input size.'}}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'This following illustration describes a 2D convolution using a kernel size of 3, stride of 1 and padding of 1.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5905832876724716369, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'autoplay': True, 'loop': True}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'There is an excellent article about detailed arithmetic (‚Äú'}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'A guide to convolution arithmetic for deep learning'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.07285', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '‚Äù)'}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.07285).', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' One may refer to it for detailed descriptions and examples for different combinations of kernel size, stride, and padding. Here I just summarize results for the most general case.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'For an input image with size of i, kernel size of k, padding of p, and stride of s, the output image from convolution has size o:'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928069073923582290, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '6. Transposed Convolution (Deconvolution)'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'For many applications and in many network architectures, we often want to do transformations going in the opposite direction of a normal convolution, i.e. we‚Äôd like to perform up-sampling. A few examples include generating high-resolution images and mapping low dimensional feature map to high dimensional space such as in auto-encoder or semantic segmentation. (In the later example, semantic segmentation first extracts feature maps in the encoder and then restores the original image size in the decoder so that it can classify every pixel in the original image.)'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Traditionally, one could achieve up-sampling by applying interpolation schemes or manually creating rules. Modern architectures such as neural networks, on the other hand, tend to let the network itself learn the proper transformation automatically, without human intervention. To achieve that, we can use the transposed convolution.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The transposed convolution is also known as deconvolution, or fractionally strided convolution in the literature. However, it‚Äôs worth noting that the name ‚Äúdeconvolution‚Äù is less appropriate, since transposed convolution is not the real deconvolution as defined in signal / image processing. Technically speaking, deconvolution in signal processing reverses the convolution operation. That is not the case here. Because of that, some authors are strongly against calling transposed convolution as deconvolution. People call it deconvolution mainly because of simplicity. Later, we will see why calling such operation as transposed convolution is natural and more appropriate.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'It is always possible to implement a transposed convolution with a direct convolution. For an example in the image below, we apply transposed convolution with a 3 x 3 kernel over a 2 x 2 input padded with a 2 x 2 border of zeros using unit strides. The up-sampled output is with size 4 x 4.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5903576030324458216, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Up-sampling a 2 x 2 input to a 4 x 4 output. Image is adopted from this '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://github.com/vdumoulin/conv_arithmetic', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'autoplay': True, 'loop': True}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Interestingly enough, one can map the same 2 x 2 input image to a different image size, by applying fancy padding & stride. Below, transposed convolution is applied over the same 2 x 2 input (with 1 zero inserted between inputs) padded with a 2 x 2 border of zeros using unit strides. Now the output is with size 5 x 5.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5896732489564554080, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Up-sampling a 2 x 2 input to a 5 x 5 output. Image is adopted from this '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://github.com/vdumoulin/conv_arithmetic', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'autoplay': True, 'loop': True}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Viewing transposed convolution in the examples above could help us build up some intuitions. But to generalize its application, it is beneficial to look at how it is implemented through matrix multiplication in computer. From there, we can also see why ‚Äútransposed convolution‚Äù is an appropriate name.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In convolution, let us define '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'C'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' as our kernel, '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Large'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' as the input image, '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Small'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' as the output image from convolution. After the convolution (matrix multiplication), we down-sample the large image into a small output image. The implementation of convolution in matrix multiplication follows as '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'C '}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'x '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Large = Small'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The following example shows how such operation works. It flattens the input to a 16 x 1 matrix, and transforms the kernel into a sparse matrix (4 x 16). The matrix multiplication is then applied between sparse matrix and the flattened input. After that, the resulting matrix (4 x 1) is then transformed back to a 2 x 2 output.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928122314338183574, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Matrix multiplication for convolution: from a Large input image (4 x 4) to a Small output image (2 x 2).'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Now, if we multiple the transpose of matrix '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'CT'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' on both sides of the equation, and use the property that multiplication of a matrix with its transposed matrix gives an Unit matrix, then we have the following formula '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'CT'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' x Small = Large, as demonstrated in the figure below.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928400512254847375, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Matrix multiplication for convolution: from a Small input image (2 x 2) to a Large output image (4 x 4).'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'As you can see here, we perform up-sampling from a small image to a large image. That is what we want to achieve. And now, you can also see where the name ‚Äútransposed convolution‚Äù comes from.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The general arithmetic for transposed convolution can be found from Relationship 13 and Relationship 14 in this excellent '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'article'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.07285', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' (‚ÄúA guide to convolution arithmetic for deep learning‚Äù).'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockSubheader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '6.1. Checkerboard artifacts.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'One unpleasant behavior that people observe when using transposed convolution is the so-called checkerboard artifacts.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5930258497927227763, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'A few examples of checkerboard artifacts. Images are adopted from this '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'paper'}, 'url': 'https://distill.pub/2016/deconv-checkerboard/', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'paper'}, 'url': 'https://distill.pub/2016/deconv-checkerboard', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' ‚ÄúDeconvolution and Checkerboard Artifacts‚Äù has an excellent description about this behavior. Please check out this article for more details. Here, I just summarize a few key points.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Checkerboard artifacts result from ‚Äúuneven overlap‚Äù of transposed convolution. Such overlap puts more of the metaphorical paint in some places than others.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In the image below, the layer on the top is the input layer, and the layer on the bottom is the output layer after transposed convolution. During transposed convolution, a layer with small size is mapped to a layer with larger size.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In the example (a), the stride is 1 and the filer size is 2. As outlined in red, the first pixel on the input maps to the first and second pixels on the output. As outlined in green, the second pixel on the input maps to the second and the third pixels on the output. The second pixel on the output receives information from both the first and the second pixels on the input. Overall, the pixels in the middle portion of the output receive same amount of information from the input. Here exist a region where kernels overlapped. As the filter size is increased to 3 in the example (b), the center portion that receives most information shrinks. But this may not be a big deal, since the overlap is still even. The pixels in the center portion of the output receive same amount of information from the input.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5930244423319398812, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The image is adopted and modified from the paper ('}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://distill.pub/2016/deconv-checkerboard/', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ').'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Now for the example below, we change stride = 2. In the example (a) where filter size = 2, all pixels on the output receive same amount of information from the input. They all receive information from a single pixel on the input. There is no overlap of transposed convolution here.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5930629449957616044, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The image is adopted and modified from the paper ('}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://distill.pub/2016/deconv-checkerboard/', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ').'}]}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'If we change the filter size to 4 in the example (b), the evenly overlapped region shrinks. But still, one can use the center portion of the output as the valid output, where each pixel receives the same amount of information from the input.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'However, things become interesting if we change the filter size to 3 and 5 in the example (c) and (d). For these two cases, every pixel on the output receives different amount of information compared to its adjacent pixels. One cannot find a continuous and evenly overlapped region on the output.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The transposed convolution has uneven overlap when the filter size is not divisible by the stride. This ‚Äúuneven overlap‚Äù puts more of the paint in some places than others, thus creates the checkerboard effects. In fact, the unevenly overlapped region tends to be more extreme in two dimensions. There, two patterns are multiplied together, the unevenness gets squared.'}}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Two things one could do to reduce such artifacts, while applying transposed convolution. First, make sure you use a filer size that is divided by your stride, avoiding the overlap issue. Secondly, one can use transposed convolution with stride = 1, which helps to reduce the checkerboard effects. However, artifacts can still leak through, as seen in many recent models.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'paper'}, 'url': 'https://distill.pub/2016/deconv-checkerboard/', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' further proposed a better up-sampling approach: resize the image first (using nearest-neighbor interpolation or bilinear interpolation) and then do a convolutional layer. By doing that, the authors avoid the checkerboard effects. You may want to try it for your applications.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '7. Dilated Convolution (Atrous Convolution)'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Dilated convolution was introduced in the '}, {'_': 'text': 'link'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1412.7062', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ') and the paper ‚ÄúMulti-scale context aggregation by dilated convolutions‚Äù ('}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'This is the standard discrete convolution:'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5928261462688639392, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockVideo', 'video_id': 5826960041466397350, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The standard This additional parameter l (dilation rate) indicates how much we want to widen the kernel. Implementations may vary, but there are usually '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'l-1'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' spaces inserted between kernel elements. Although all three dilated convolutions provide the output with the same dimension, the receptive field observed by the model is dramatically different. The receptive filed is 3 x 3 for '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'l =1'}}, {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. '}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'It is 7 x 7 for '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'l =2'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '. Interestingly, the numbers of parameters associated with these operations are essentially identical. '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'We ‚Äúobserve‚Äù a large receptive filed without adding additional costs.'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' Because of that, dilated convolution is used to cheaply increase the receptive field of output units without increasing the kernel size, which is especially effective when multiple dilated convolutions are stacked one after another.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The authors in the paper ‚ÄúMulti-scale context aggregation by dilated convolutions‚Äù build a network out of multiple layers of dilated convolutions, where the dilation rate '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'l'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' increases exponentially at each layer. As a result, the effective receptive field grows exponentially while the number of parameters grows only linearly with layers!'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The dilated convolution in the paper is used to systematically aggregate multi-scale contextual information without losing resolution. The paper shows that the proposed module increases the accuracy of state-of-the-art semantic segmentation systems at that time (2016). Please check out the paper for more information.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockHeader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '8. Separable Convolutions'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Separable Convolutions are used in some neural net architectures, such as the MobileNet ('}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Link'}, 'url': 'https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.04861', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '). One can perform separable convolution spatially (spatially separable convolution) or depthwise (depthwise separable convolution).'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockSubheader', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '8.1. Spatially Separable Convolutions'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The spatially separable convolution operates on the 2D spatial dimensions of images, i.e. height and width. Conceptually, spatially separable convolution decomposes a convolution into two separate operations. For an example shown below, a Sobel kernel, which is a 3x3 kernel, is divided into a 3x1 and 1x3 kernel.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5973176989424658960, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'A Sobel kernel can be divided into a 3 x 1 and a 1 x 3 kernel.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'In convolution, the 3x3 kernel directly convolves with the image. In spatially separable convolution, the 3x1 kernel first convolves with the image. Then the 1x3 kernel is applied. This would require 6 instead of 9 parameters while doing the same operations.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Moreover, one need less matrix multiplications in spatially separable convolution than convolution. For a concrete example, convolution on a 5 x 5 image with a 3 x 3 kernel (stride=1, padding=0) requires scanning the kernel at 3 positions horizontally (and 3 positions vertically). That is 9 positions in total, indicated as the dots in the image below. At each position, 9 element-wise multiplications are applied. Overall, that‚Äôs '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '9 x 9 = 81'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' multiplications.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5973266118585985555, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Standard convolution with 1 channel.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'On the other hand, for spatially separable convolution, we first apply a 3 x 1 filter on the 5 x 5 image. We scan such kernel at 5 positions horizontally and 3 positions vertically. That‚Äôs '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '5 x 3=15 '}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'positions in total, indicated as dots on the image below. At each position, 3 element-wise multiplications are applied. That is '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '15 x 3 = 45'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' multiplications. We now obtained a 3 x 5 matrix. This matrix is now convolved with a 1 x 3 kernel, which scans the matrix at 3 positions horizontally and 3 positions vertically. For each of these 9 positions, 3 element-wise multiplications are applied. This step requires'}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' 9 x 3=27 '}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'multiplications. Thus, overall, the spatially separable convolution takes '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '45 + 27 = 72 '}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'multiplications, which is less than convolution.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5975154718785251671, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Spatially separable convolution with 1 channel.'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Let‚Äôs generalize the above examples a little bit. Let‚Äôs say we now apply convolutions on a N x N image with a m x m kernel, with stride=1 and padding=0. Traditional convolution requires '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '(N-2) x (N-2) x m x m'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' multiplications. Spatially separable convolution requires '}, {'_': 'TextItalic', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'N x (N-2) x m + (N-2) x (N-2) x m = (2N-2) x (N-2) x m'}}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' multiplications. The ratio of computation costs between spatially separable convolution and the standard convolution is'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockPhoto', 'photo_id': 5975631593299093896, 'caption': {'_': 'PageCaption', 'text': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}, 'credit': {'_': 'TextEmpty'}}, 'url': None, 'webpage_id': None}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'For layers where the image size N is larger than filter size (N >> m), this ratio becomes 2 / m. It means at this asymptotic situation (N >> m), computational cost of spatially separable convolution is 2/3 of the standard convolution for a 3 x 3 filter. It is 2 / 5 for a 5 x 5 filter, 2 / 7 for a 7 x 7 filter, and so on.'}}], 'photos': [{'_': 'Photo', 'id': 5928065058129160564, 'access_hash': 4030689650981471662, 'file_reference': b'\x00et\xe9\xb4\xa3\xea\x91\tf\xe5\xe8t\x07^+/\xe6\xd2\xb5|', 'date': datetime.datetime(2019, 8, 5, 10, 50, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'sizes': [{'_': 'PhotoStrippedSize', 'type': 'i', message : List of Free Natural Language Processing Courses

1)Speech and Language Processing by Dan Jurafsky and James Martin
https://web.stanford.edu/~jurafsky/slp3/

2) Deep Learning for Natural Language Processing¬†by Richard Socher (Stanford University)
https://m.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3FW7Lu3i5Jsnh1rnUwq_TcylNr7EkRe6

3. Natural Language Processing (NLP)¬†by Microsoft
https://www.edx.org/course/natural-language-processing-nlp-2

4. Andrew Ng‚Äôs course on¬†Machine Learning
https://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning/home/welcome

5. The¬†video lectures¬†and¬†resources¬†for Stanford‚Äôs¬†Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning
http://web.stanford.edu/class/cs224n/

https://m.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3FW7Lu3i5Jsnh1rnUwq_TcylNr7EkRe6


6. Sequence Models for Time Series and Natural Language Processing¬†
https://www.coursera.org/learn/sequence-models-tensorflow-gcp?ranMID=40328&ranEAID=SAyYsTvLiGQ&ranSiteID=SAyYsTvLiGQ-ACNikbtJvh2d5Evme5yZQA&siteID=SAyYsTvLiGQ-ACNikbtJvh2d5Evme5yZQA&utm_content=10&utm_medium=partners&utm_source=linkshare&utm_campaign=SAyYsTvLiGQ

7. Deep Natural Language Processing¬†course offered in Hilary Term 2017 at the University of Oxford.
http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/teaching/courses/2016-2017/dl/

8. Natural Language Processing Fundamentals in Python¬†by Datacamp
https://www.datacamp.com/courses/natural-language-processing-fundamentals-in-python

9 Natural Language Processing¬†by Higher School of Economics
https://www.coursera.org/learn/language-processing?

10 How to Build a Chatbot Without Coding¬†by IBM
https://www.coursera.org/learn/building-ai-powered-chatbots

11. CS 388: Natural Language Processing¬†by University of Texas
https://www.cs.utexas.edu/~mooney/cs388/

12. Natural Language Processing¬†with Python
http://www.nltk.org/book/

13. CSEP 517: Natural Language Processing¬†by University of Washington
https://courses.cs.washington.edu/courses/csep517/17sp/

14. Dan Jurafsky & Chris Manning: Natural Language Processing
https://m.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8FFE3F391203C98C

15. NATURAL LANGUAGE PROCESSING¬†by Carnegie Mellon University
http://demo.clab.cs.cmu.edu/NLP/

16. CS224n: Natural Language Processing with Deep Learning¬†by Stanford University
http://web.stanford.edu/class/cs224n/

Note:  If you find some more AI courses which are free then please feel free to send us via email. Our email is ai.india.ml@gmail.com 

We will add your name here in the list at the bottom.

message : Paper on Reinforcement Learning
 ‚ÄúReinforcement Learning, Fast and Slow‚Äù, reviews recent techniques in deep RL that narrow the gap in learning speed. The rapidly developing field of deep RL holds great interest for psychology and neuroscience, given its integrated focus on representation learning and goal-directed behavior.
https://www.cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences/fulltext/S1364-6613(19)30061-0
out : False
mentioned : False
media_unread : False
silent : True
post : True
from_scheduled : False
legacy : False
edit_hide : True
pinned : False
noforwards : False
invert_media : False
from_id : None
fwd_from : None
via_bot_id : None
reply_to : None
media : {'_': 'MessageMediaWebPage', 'webpage': {'_': 'WebPage', 'id': 4549408350239110126, 'url': 'https://www.cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences/fulltext/S1364-6613(19)30061-0', 'display_url': 'cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences/fulltext/S1364-6613(19)30061-0', 'hash': 0, 'has_large_media': True, 'type': 'photo', 'site_name': 'Trends in Cognitive Sciences', 'title': 'Reinforcement Learning, Fast and Slow', 'description': 'Deep reinforcement learning (RL) methods have driven impressive advances in artificial\nintelligence in recent years, exceeding human performance in domains ranging from\nAtari to Go to no-limit poker. This progress has drawn the attention of cognitive\nscientists interested in understanding human learning. However, the concern has been\nraised that deep RL may be too sample-inefficient ‚Äì that is, it may simply be too\nslow ‚Äì to provide a plausible model of how humans learn. In the present review, we\ncounter this critique by describing recently developed techniques that allow deep\nRL to operate more nimbly, solving problems much more quickly than previous methods.', 'photo': {'_': 'Photo', 'id': 5781798589654215200, 'access_hash': 8910720462340499450, 'file_reference': b'\x00et\xe9\xb4\x86\xc6(n\x8e\xd7\x85\x92\x04]\xa6v\xa7\x82\xfcd', 'date': datetime.datetime(2019, 9, 21, 22, 30, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'sizes': [{'_': 'PhotoStrippedSize', 'type': 'i', 'bytes': b'\x01\x11(\xd7\x00Tb@xQ\x80y\x04\xf7\xa9H\xc8\xc1\xa6\x05U\xe4\x0e\x9c\x0e(\x01U\xb3\xd7\x07\xe9K\x9e\t\x1e\x94\x0eFM\x01@\xe3\xb5\x00"\xb9\xcf8\xc5\x14\xecq\x8a)\x08Z(\xa2\x98\xc2\x91\xbe\xe9\xfaQE\x00T\x1fz\x8a(\xa0\x0f'}, {'_': 'PhotoSize', 'type': 'm', 'w': 320, 'h': 139, 'size': 12078}, {'_': 'PhotoSize', 'type': 'x', 'w': 560, 'h': 243, 'size': 25988}], 'dc_id': 4, 'has_stickers': False, 'video_sizes': []}, 'embed_url': None, 'embed_type': None, 'embed_width': None, 'embed_height': None, 'duration': None, 'author': None, 'document': None, 'cached_page': None, 'attributes': []}, 'force_large_media': False, 'force_small_media': False, 'manual': False, 'safe': True}

id : 106
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2019-03-31 17:47:35+00:00
message : OpenCV is truly an all emcompassing library for computer vision tasks. OpenCV is continually adding new modules for latest algorithms form Machine learning, do check out their Github repository and get familiar with implementation. You can even contribute to the library which is a great way to learn and interact with the community. 
There are some common challenges data scientists face when transitioning into computer vision, including:

1. The ever-present problem of acquiring data. Should we collect more images before building our computer vision model?

 2. How do we clean image datasets? Images come in different shapes and sizes 

 3. Is learning deep learning compulsory for building computer vision models? Can we not use machine learning techniques?

 4. Can we build a computer vsiion model on our own machine? Not everyone has access to GPUs and TPUs!

 more to read : https://bit.ly/2JZRxxg

Solving a problem also forces you to deeply engage with machine learning, instead of passively reading about it.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Good problems to start with have several criteria:'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockList', 'items': [{'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'They cover an area you‚Äôre personally interested in.'}}, {'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Data is readily available that‚Äôs well-suited to addressing the problem (otherwise the bulk of your time will go here).'}}, {'_': 'PageListItemText', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'You can work with the data (or some relevant subset of it) comfortably on a single machine.'}}]}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Don‚Äôt have a problem that comes to mind? No worries! We provide a nice onramp of machine learning problems at Kaggle through our getting started competition series. Start off on the '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'titanic competition'}, 'url': 'https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '2. Make a quick, dirty, hacky, end-to-end solution to your problem.'}}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'It‚Äôs really easy to get bogged down in one implementation detail or carefully tuning the wrong machine learning algorithm. You want to avoid this.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Your goal here is to get something super basic in place as quickly as possible that covers the end-to-end problem, from reading in the data, processing it into a form suitable for machine learning, training a basic model, creating a result, and evaluating its performance.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '3. Evolve and improve your initial solution.'}}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Now that you have a functional baseline, it‚Äôs time to get creative. Try improving each component of your initial solution, and measure the impact to see where it makes sense to spend time. Many times acquiring more data or improving data cleaning and preprocessing steps have a higher ROI than optimizing the machine learning models themselves.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Part of this step should include being hands-on with the data - inspecting individual rows and visualizing distributions to have a better understanding of its structure and oddities.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '4. Write up and share your solution.'}}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The best way to get feedback on your solution is to write it up and share it. Writing about your solution mean you‚Äôll engage with it in a new way and understand it better. This enables others to understand what you‚Äôve done and provide feedback, helping you learn. It also kickstarts your machine learning portfolio, which will help showcase your abilities and get a job.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kaggle Datasets'}, 'url': 'https://www.kaggle.com/datasets', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' and '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kaggle Kernels'}, 'url': 'https://www.kaggle.com/datasets', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' are an effective way to share your data and solution, get feedback from others, and also see how others extend your problem. This starts fleshing out your Kaggle profile as well.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '5. Repeat #1-4 across a diverse set of problems.'}}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Now that you‚Äôve done this for a single problem that you‚Äôre interested in, do this several more times across a different set of domains.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Did you start off with tabular data? Work on a problem that involves less structured text, and another that solves images.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Was the machine learning problem structured for you initially? A lot of the creative and valuable work is figuring out how to go from a loosely-defined business or research objective to a well-defined machine learning problem in the first place. Work through this for one problem type.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextConcat', 'texts': [{'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kaggle Competitions'}, 'url': 'https://www.kaggle.com/competitions', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' and '}, {'_': 'TextUrl', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kaggle Datasets'}, 'url': 'https://www.kaggle.com/datasets', 'webpage_id': 0}, {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': ' provide a good starting point for both well-defined machine learning problems and raw data sources that‚Äôd be suitable for machine learning.'}]}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextBold', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': '6. Seriously compete in a Kaggle competition (if you‚Äôve not already done so).'}}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Giving your best shot at the same problem that thousands of others are hard at work on is a tremendous learning opportunity: it forces you to iterate on the problem over and over again, and then exposes you to what works effectively on the problem.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'The forums for an individual competition are a rich resource on how others are approaching it and debugging issues with your approach, kernels provide exploratory insights about the data along with an easy way to get started on a problem, and the winning blog posts at the end showcase what ultimately worked best.'}}, {'_': 'PageBlockParagraph', 'text': {'_': 'TextPlain', 'text': 'Kaggle Competitions also provide a unique opportunity to team up with others. Deciding on the type of role you‚Äôd like to pursue and building a personal portfolio of projects related to this is a strong starting point. If you‚Äôre not ready to start interviewing for machine learning positions, then taking on new projects in your current role, seeking consulting opportunities, and getting involved with civic hackathons and data-related community service opportunities are additional ways to get a foothold. message : Master ML Algorithm by Jason Brownlee
 Machine learning algorithms dominate applied machine learning. Because algorithms are such a big part of machine learning you must spend time to get familiar with them and really understand how they work. This book to help you start this journey. You can describe machine learning algorithms using statistics, probability and linear algebra. The mathematical descriptions are very precise and often unambiguous. 
   This book cuts through the mathematical talk around machine learning algorithms and shows you exactly how they work so that you can implement them yourself in a spreadsheet, in code with your favorite programming language or however you like.

_ : Message
id : 35
peer_id : {'_': 'PeerChannel', 'channel_id': 1450543193}
date : 2019-03-02 17:21:50+00:00
message : For small businesses, analyzing the information contained in their data using open source technology could be game-changing. All you need is some basic programming and mathematical skills to do just that.

Overview

Explore how to analyze your data in various innovative ways and turn them into insightLearn to use the D3.js visualization tool for exploratory data analysisUnderstand how to work with graphs and social data analysisDiscover how to perform advanced query techniques and run MapReduce on MongoDB

In Detail

Plenty of small businesses face big amounts of data but lack the internal skills to support quantitative analysis. Understanding how to harness the power of data analysis using the latest open source technology can lead them to providing better customer service, the visualization of customer needs, or even the ability to obtain fresh insights about the performance of previous products. Practical Data Analysis is a book ideal for home and small business users who want to slice and dice the data they have on hand with minimum hassle.

Practical Data Analysis is a hands-on guide to understanding the nature of your data and turn it into insight. It will introduce you to the use of machine learning techniques, social networks analytics, and econometrics to help your clients get insights about the pool of data they have at hand. Performing data preparation and processing over several kinds of data such as text, images, graphs, documents, and time series will also be covered.

Practical Data Analysis presents a detailed exploration of the current work in data analysis through self-contained projects. First you will explore the basics of data preparation and transformation through OpenRefine. Then you will get started with exploratory data analysis using the D3js visualization framework. You will also be introduced to some of the machine learning techniques such as, classification, regression, and clusterization through practical projects such as spam classification, predicting gold prices, and finding clusters in your Facebook friends' network. You will learn how to solve problems in text classification, simulation, time series forecast, social media, and MapReduce through detailed projects. Finally you will work with large amounts of Twitter data using MapReduce to perform a sentiment analysis implemented in Python and MongoDB.

Practical Data Analysis contains a combination of carefully selected algorithms and data scrubbing that enables you to turn your data into insight.
